popt4jlib

Class IntArray1SparseVector

  • java.lang.Object
    • popt4jlib.IntArray1SparseVector
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, SparseVectorIntf, VectorIntf

    public class IntArray1SparseVector
extends java.lang.Object
implements SparseVectorIntf
    sparse int[] implementation of VectorIntf, maintaining two arrays, an index array, and a values array. Useful when dealing with very high-dimensional vectors that are sparse to a significant degree (e.g. in Graph Theory, one may create vectors in as many dimensions as there are nodes in the graph, but each vector may have only as many non-zero components as it has immediate neighbors). Notice that getCoord/setCoord operations can be much more costly than the same operations when operating with a DblArray1Vector (where the operations are O(1) -constant time simple memory accesses). But on the other hand, iterations over the non-zero elements can be made much faster, as well as related inner-product operations etc. Notice also that the class is not thread-safe, i.e. none of the methods can be considered as reentrant in a multi-threaded environment. This choice is made for speed considerations. Clients must therefore ensure on their own that the application is race-condition free when using this class. Notice also that this class only supports zero as the default value of components.

    Title: popt4jlib

    Description: A Parallel Meta-Heuristic Optimization Library in Java

    Copyright: Copyright (c) 2015

    Company:

    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    Ioannis T. Christou
    See Also:

      • IntArray1SparseVector

        private IntArray1SparseVector(int[] indices,
                              double[] values,
                              int n)
                       throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        private constructor.
        Parameters:
        indices - int[] must be in ascending order
        values - double[] corresponds to int values for each index in the indices array
        n - int total length of the vector
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if indices and values don't match or are null or if n is too small or if indices are not stored in ascending order or if values do not hold int values or if some of its components are zero

      • IntArray1SparseVector

        private IntArray1SparseVector(int[] indices,
                              double[] values,
                              int n,
                              double multFactor)
                       throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        private constructor representing the (sparse) vector that results from multiplying every element in the sparse-array representation given by the first three arguments with the value given in the fourth argument, and keeping only the integer part of the multiplication. Note: this constructor assumes indices and values have length exactly as much as the _ilen of the newly constructed vector should be.
        Parameters:
        indices - int[] elements must be in ascending order
        values - double[]
        n - int
        multFactor - double
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if indices and values don't match or are null or if n is too small or if indices are not stored in ascending order or if some component of values is zero

      • getCoord

        public double getCoord(int i)
                throws java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException
        return the i-th coordinate of this VectorIntf (i must be in the set {0,1,2,...getNumCoords()-1}). Has O(log(_ilen)) worst-case time-complexity where _ilen is the (max.) number of non-zeros in this vector.
        Specified by:
        getCoord in interface VectorIntf
        Parameters:
        i - int
        Returns:
        double holding an integer quantity
        Throws:
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if i is not in the set mentioned above

      • setCoord

        public void setCoord(int i,
                     double val)
              throws java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException,
                     java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        set the i-th coordinate of this VectorIntf (i must be in the set {0,1,2,...getNumCoords()-1}). Repeated calls to this method for indices not in the original construction of this vector will eventually destroy its sparsity. Has O(_ilen) worst-case time-complexity where _ilen is the (max.) number of non-zeros in the array. The time-complexity reduces to O(log(_ilen)) if the element to be set, is already non-zero before the operation.
        Specified by:
        setCoord in interface VectorIntf
        Parameters:
        i - int
        val - double must hold an integer value
        Throws:
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if i is not in the set mentioned above
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - -if val does not represent an integer

      • getIthNonZeroPos

        public int getIthNonZeroPos(int i)
                     throws java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException
        the purpose of this routine is to allow a traversal of the non-zeros of this object as follows: 
         
 for (int i=0; i<sparsevector.getNumNonZeros(); i++) {
   int    pos = sparsevector.getIthNonZeroPos(i);
   int    val = sparsevector.getIthNonZeroVal(i);
   // int val = (int) sparsevector.getCoord(pos);
 }
        Specified by:
        getIthNonZeroPos in interface SparseVectorIntf
        Parameters:
        i - int
        Returns:
        int
        Throws:
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if i is out-of-bounds. Always throws if this is the zero vector

      • innerProduct

        public double innerProduct(VectorIntf other)
                    throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        compute the inner product of this vector with the argument passed in. The operation should be fast when this vector is sparse enough, as it only goes through the non-zero elements of the vector.

        Throws:
